completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or
parents and the foster parents in the development
of service plans to enable the parent or parents
and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role
in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An
agency shall give a copy to and review the parent-
agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan
and any other information about the child and the
child's family is confidential.
Three of six foster care case records reviewed did not indicate that the plan was
developed with the parent/parents or foster parents to enable the
parent/parents/foster parents to understand the plan.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the individual CAP is as follows:
The agency Renewal inspection was completed on 02/16/24 and the CAP was
completed on 02/26/2024. The agency was found in noncompliance with DHHS
policies 722.08D which is no longer regulated by DCWL. There are no repeat
violations, but the agency is struggling with getting the Parent Agency Treatment
Plans signed timely to indicate the responsible party was involved. Overall, the
agency is making efforts to improve this noncompliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed with the Chief
Administrator (CA) onsite 05/14/2025. The CA reported barriers and systemic
factors that impacted rules, ISEP, policy and contract compliance which included
high staff turnover. The CA reported the previous CAP was not successful due to
high staff turnover and all processes were not always being followed. The
Corrective Action Plan (CAP) has brought attention to areas that need oversight
and improvement. It has provided supervisory guidelines to improve compliance
and tracking with departmental reports to assist with task completion due dates
and reminders. The CAP was provided to the staff with a check and balance
system to ensure all metrics are met per policy and ISEP. The CAP provided staff
with refresher training to improve quality of work. Also, the CAP enforced
supervisory accountability to ensure staff are adhering to policy and ISEP
standards.
Financial Overview:
The agency annual audit by an independent certified public accountant dated
9/30/24 and their annual budget were reviewed. No concerns were noted.
3

Staff Interviews:
Three staff were interviewed, and they reported they enjoyed working at the
agency. The staff reported they are supported by their supervisors and coworkers.
Staff reported they would love to receive more recognition for the job duties from
higher administration.
Description of Agency Walk Through:
The building has adequate space to provide the required services, and the record
maintenance were stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
